--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "tcfolsom" <Todd.Folsom@s...> wrote:
> Go to www.mockmaker.org and download the mockmaker tool. Then apply 
> it to interfaces or classes for which you need mocks. These new 
mocks 
> will have methods for setting their state, and all support the 
verify
> () method. YOur mockRepository can be configured to return a 
> mockRepositoryView and to verify that a call was made to that 
method. 
> For instance if your code should call getRepositoryView(), you set 
up 
> MockRepository with setExpectedGetRepositoryViewCalls(1). This 
method 
> is built in the mock for you by the mockmaker tool. Verify() will 
> check that a single call of getRepositoryView was made on the mock. 
>   This is very useful stuff. However you may have to refactor your 
> code to make it possible to supply a mock object instead of the 
real 
> object. If you work from interfaces, it is easier to handle mocks. 
> For example if getRepostoryView returns a RepositoryViewInterface 
> rather than a RepositoryView, it is easy to return a 
> MockRepositoryView which implemented RepositoryViewInterface.
> 
> 
> --- In junit@y..., "cilqproj" <cilqproj@y...> wrote:
> > The problem is that I'm struggling to test a pretty complex piece 
of
> > code and I'm trying to get some advice ( hints, help, etc .. ) to 
> help
> > me tackle it.  
> > 
> > In the real world, I use ATG Dynamo.  If you've heard of it or 
used
> > it, it's an App Server / EJB Container.   Dynamo's entire 
framework 
> is
> > based off this component known as Nucleus, which does a lot of 
work 
> in
> > terms of instantiating classes, setting properties, etc..  It's 
also
> > very slow and to test - build - test takes forever if I have to 
> start
> > and stop the app-server for every change in the code. 
> > 
> > That's where MockObjects come in.  Dynamo is a very Java Beans 
heavy
> > framework, that relies a lot on setters and getters.  ( In fact, 
the
> > MockObjects guys at SF have started putting together some Dynamo
> > MockObjects. ) I was looking into MockObjects as a way to lessen 
my
> > reliance on the Nucleus namespace so that I could code quickly and
> > only integrate with the Nucleus namespace at the latest possible 
> time.
> > 
> > However, I can't get my head around the fact that in certain 
cases 
> my
> > mock code will need to generate other mock code 
> > 
> > Here's a method from a piece of old code that I wrote before I 
> decided
> > to start using JUnit:
> > 
> >     public  Map generateEmptyPreferencesMap( Map m ) throws
> > RepositoryException {
> > 
> > 	// get the list of possible preferences
> > 	RepositoryView contactMethodView = getPreferencesRepository
> ().getView(
> > CONTACT_METHOD_REPOSITORY_ITEM );
> > 	RepositoryItem[] contactMethods = 
> contactMethodView.executeQuery(
> > contactMethodView.getQueryBuilder().createUnconstrainedQuery() );
> > 	
> > 	if ( ( contactMethods != null ) && ( contactMethods.length > 
> 0 ) )  {
> > 	    // add each one to the map
> > 	    for ( int i = 0 ; i < contactMethods.length ; i++ ) {
> > 		m.put( contactMethods[i].getPropertyValue(
> > CONTACT_METHOD_CODE_PROPERTY_NAME ), new BooleanPlaceHolder() );
> > 	    }
> > 	}
> >      return m;
> >     }
> >      
> > 
> > The Repository API is Dynamo's object-oriented data abstraction 
> api. 
> > In this case, I assume I would setPreferencesRepository( new
> > MyMockRepository()  )
> > 
> > but that MockRepository needs to return a MockRepositoryView 
which 
> in
> > turn needs to return a MockQueryBuilder, or so I seem to believe.
> > 
> > In a sentence:  how would one test this?  
> > 
> > As before,
> > Any and all help is greatly appreciated.
> > 
> > I apologize for any unnecessary lengthiness.
> > 
> > Thanks,
> >
